speaker Stewart McLaren the president of the White House Historical Association
so Stewart was appointed as the president of the White House Historical Association in May of 2014 his career
spans the nonprofit education in public policy fields he's previously held
senior positions with the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation Georgetown University and the American Red Cross
welcome Stewart good afternoon everyone
it's great to be with you here and before I begin I want to introduce three great colleagues that are with me today
stephanie joanna and whitney and they'll be here all week at this conference as well as education conference that can
elaborate on what we're doing and share more in depth with you about the exciting things we have planned for the
future so to begin I think I should tell you just a little bit about who we are and what we do
everybody knows the American Heart Association but not everyone knows the White House Historical Association we're
a nonprofit nonpartisan organization that is not affiliated politically with
any party or any president we've been around since 1961 when First Lady
Jacqueline Kennedy founded the Association remember she was only 31 years old when her husband was elected
president of the United States she came into this house which had been radically renovated by President Truman it was
completely gutted and when it was refurbished the government nor Truman
could afford to furnish it as mrs. Kennedy would have wanted it furnished so as largely for
with department store renovation furniture mrs. Kennedy came in and said no this will not do it needs to be the
very highest standard for the country representing the best of America in terms of art furniture furnishings but
you couldn't do this with government funding so she needed a private partner to do this and so she created the White
House Historical Association so in 1961 we became this nonprofit entity to raise
money we don't accept any government funding whatsoever and we worked collaboratively with every president and
first lady since the Kennedys and we've contributed about 50 million dollars in
projects back to the White House but mrs. Kennedy also had a great vision
beyond what to do in with and for the White House she had a vision that was
education in nature and that's where our partnership with AWS comes in she wanted
to teach and tell the stories of the White House going back to 1792 with
George Washington selected that swampy piece of land in Washington and the White House was built but in the 1960s
you don't have the wonderful tools and toys that we have today so what she did was she printed the very first guidebook
to tour the White House and that's this the predecessor to that book on the top
right the first one was 1961 and we've continued to update and publish this
book as the White House has been updated and its furnishings and its inhabitants changed last fall we published the 24th
edition of this book oh that's great we have wonderful programs we have teacher
Institute's we have curriculum that's on our website to go out into the schools we do a lot we publish other books we'll
do six unique titles on the White House this year and a quarterly magazine and although that's great but what I
realized what my team and I realized a few years ago is that we're hunkered down in Washington right across the
street from the White House we have all this amazing rich wonderful content but
we had no reach to connect that content with schools classrooms students across
the country and with other people interested in history in the white house not only in our country but around the world
so we began this partnership with Amazon Web Services and you know I'll use the
Amazon phrase of revolution e'en Aryan evolutionary we drank the kool-aid because we saw this was a collaborative
collaboration that we could take our wonderful content and deploy it at first
through a White House Tour Apple because from 1961 when mrs. Kennedy published that first book until 2017 18 that's all
you had about 500,000 people a year have the opportunity to tour the White House
and it's all a self-guided tour so unless you know what you're looking at you don't know what you're looking at
well that has all changed now so in the past few months we have debuted with
Amazon Web Services this extraordinary first ever White House tour app when you
go on a White House Tour you do that through your congressman and you're sent a boarding pass from the White House and
that gives you all the information what you can bring what you cannot bring what you can do and starting this month that
boarding pass will have information on this app so people who are going to visit the White House can download it
and prepare for their visit and then as they go through the White House they can see the key points of every room every
piece of furniture the key pieces of furniture the key paintings and all the elements that will bring the White House
to life for them and this has never been available before the tour has three key
components those who do have the opportunity to go through the White House and they're about 500,000 people a
year that the actual White House gets to go through which is pretty amazing considering if you've ever been how many
people actually been on a tour of the White House great well by the end of today everybody can go on a tour of the

experience or search white house experience you can download this app and there are three tours there's the tour
that if you're actually going to go through the White House and you room-to-room see what you're seeing there's a wonderful walking tour around
the president's neighborhood so if you're in Washington and you don't have an opportunity to actually go into the White House you can look at it and see
the floor plans and see the rooms and see the buildings in what we call presidents Park or the president's neighborhood and bring that to life
